moe_section_title: Use of Subcontractors and Temporary Line Maintenance Locations
summary: The section states, in a very unclear and contradictory way, that the maintenance organisation does not use subcontractors. It also briefly mentions a catalogue of temporary line maintenance points and a maintenance certificate giving catalogue, but without any explanation, procedures, or lists.

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.75(d) / AMC1 145.A.75(b) & 3.1–3.6 (subcontracting fundamentals and need for MOE procedure and list)
findings.requirement_excerpt: Authorisation to sub-contract is indicated by the competent authority approving the MOE containing a specific procedure on the control of subcontractors as well as a list of subcontractors.
findings.reasoning: The MOE text only says 'No use subcontractors' and provides no procedure for control of subcontractors, no description of how subcontracted work would be managed under the organisation’s approval, and no list of subcontractors. It is also internally inconsistent because it refers to a 'CATALOG SUBCONTRACTING' while stating that no subcontractors are used. If the organisation truly does not subcontract, the MOE should clearly state this and remove or neutralise references to subcontracting catalogues; if it does subcontract, the required procedures and lists are missing.
findings.recommended_fix:
Clarify the organisation’s policy and align the text accordingly. Two options:

1) If the organisation does NOT subcontract any maintenance under its approval:
"The organisation does not subcontract any maintenance activities under its Part-145 approval. All maintenance is performed and released under the organisation’s own facilities, personnel, tools, equipment and procedures. No subcontractors are used under 145.A.75(b) / AMC1 145.A.75(b). Should the organisation decide to use subcontractors in the future, this MOE will be revised to include a detailed procedure for the control of subcontractors and a list of approved subcontractors in accordance with AMC1 145.A.75(b) and 145.A.205."
Remove or rename any headings such as "CATALOG SUBCONTRACTING" that suggest subcontractor use, or explicitly state "Not applicable – no subcontractors used" under that heading.

2) If the organisation DOES subcontract:
Add a full procedure section, for example:
"X.X Control of Subcontractors
(a) Policy
The organisation may subcontract certain maintenance tasks under its Part-145 approval in accordance with 145.A.75(b), AMC1 145.A.75(b) and 145.A.205. The subcontracted organisation works under the management system and approval of this organisation.
(b) Scope of subcontracted work
Describe which types of work may be subcontracted (e.g. specialised processes, specific line tasks, component work) and ensure they are within the organisation’s own scope of approval.
(c) Selection and pre-audit
Before adding a subcontractor, the Compliance Monitoring function performs and documents a pre-audit to verify that the subcontractor’s facilities, personnel, tools, equipment, maintenance data and procedures meet the intent of Part-145 and this MOE.
(d) Contract and interfaces
The contract defines responsibilities, use of facilities, tools, maintenance data and paperwork, and establishes interfaces for occurrence and internal safety reporting.
(e) Oversight and monitoring
Subcontracted activities are included in the hazard identification, risk management and compliance monitoring programme. Periodic audits are performed and recorded.
(f) List of subcontractors
An up-to-date list of approved subcontractors, including scope of work and locations, is maintained in Appendix XX of this MOE."
Then create and maintain the referenced subcontractor list appendix.

findings.requirement_excerpt: The organisation shall ensure that when contracting or subcontracting any part of its maintenance activities: (1) the maintenance conforms to the applicable requirements; (2) any aviation safety hazard associated with such contracting or subcontracting is considered as part of the organisation’s management system. If the organisation subcontracts any part of its maintenance activities to another organisation, the subcontracted organisation shall work under the scope of approval of the subcontracting organisation.
findings.reasoning: The MOE section does not describe how the organisation ensures conformity of contracted/subcontracted maintenance, how hazards from such arrangements are identified and managed within the management system, or how interfaces and communication with contracted/subcontracted organisations are handled. Simply stating 'No use subcontractors' does not address contracting (other Part-145 organisations releasing under their own approval) and does not provide any management-system linkage if subcontracting were to occur.
findings.recommended_fix:
Add a dedicated MOE subsection on contracting and, if applicable, subcontracting, for example:
"X.X Contracting and Subcontracting of Maintenance
(a) General
When contracting maintenance to another Part-145 organisation (contracting) or subcontracting maintenance under our approval (subcontracting), the organisation remains responsible for ensuring that:
  • all contracted/subcontracted maintenance conforms to applicable requirements; and
  • hazards associated with such arrangements are identified, assessed and controlled within the management system in accordance with 145.A.200(a)(3).
(b) Contracting maintenance
When maintenance is contracted to another Part-145 organisation that releases the work under its own approval:
  • the Compliance Monitoring function verifies that the contracted organisation’s approval covers the contracted tasks and remains valid;
  • interfaces for occurrence reporting and internal safety reporting are established; and
  • complex arrangements involving multiple contracted organisations are assessed for interface risks.
(c) Subcontracting maintenance
Where maintenance is subcontracted under our approval (if applicable), the subcontracted organisation works under our management system and approval. The control of such subcontractors is performed in accordance with procedure X.X (Control of Subcontractors). Hazards and risks from subcontracted activities are included in our hazard identification and risk management processes, and in our compliance monitoring programme."
If the organisation truly neither contracts nor subcontracts any maintenance, explicitly state this and reference where in the MOE such activities would be addressed if introduced in future.

findings.requirement_id: AMC1 145.A.75(b) 3.2–3.4 & 4.1–4.3 (subcontractor working under Part-145 management system and need for detailed control procedures)
findings.requirement_excerpt: All parts of the subcontractor involved with the maintenance organisation’s products undergoing maintenance should meet Part-145 requirements and the Part-145 organisation’s MOE for the duration of that maintenance, and it remains the Part-145 organisation’s responsibility to ensure such requirements are satisfied. … Authorisation to sub-contract is indicated by the competent authority approving the MOE containing a specific procedure on the control of subcontractors as well as a list of subcontractors. A pre-audit procedure should be established… Unless the sub-contracted maintenance work can be fully inspected on receipt… it will be necessary for the Part-145 organisation to establish an MOE procedure to control the subcontracted maintenance work (and associated supporting documents).
findings.reasoning: The MOE section does not describe how the organisation ensures that subcontractor facilities, personnel, tools, equipment, maintenance data and procedures comply with Part-145 and the MOE, nor does it describe pre-audits, ongoing oversight, use of subcontractor paperwork, or control of subcontracted work and supporting documents. The brief and contradictory wording provides no usable procedure for competent authority approval.
findings.recommended_fix:
If subcontracting is or may be used, expand the MOE with a detailed procedure consistent with AMC1 145.A.75(b), for example:
"X.X.1 Pre-audit and approval of subcontractors
(a) Before any subcontractor is used, the Compliance Monitoring function performs a documented pre-audit covering:
  • facilities and environmental conditions;
  • personnel qualifications and authorisations;
  • tools, equipment and calibration;
  • maintenance data and procedures;
  • quality/compliance monitoring arrangements.
(b) The results are reviewed by the nominated postholder/manager responsible for maintenance, who decides on acceptance and inclusion in the subcontractor list.

X.X.2 Control of subcontracted work
(a) The contract specifies whether our facilities, tools, maintenance data and paperwork are used, or those of the subcontractor, provided they meet Part-145 requirements and are accepted by us.
(b) For work that cannot be fully inspected on receipt, we:
  • define inspection/hold points;
  • either send our certifying staff/inspectors to the subcontractor’s facility, or
  • formally authorise specific subcontractor personnel to perform defined inspections on our behalf, under our procedures.
(c) All subcontracted work packages and supporting documents are reviewed and accepted by our organisation before issuing the certificate of release to service.

X.X.3 Subcontractor list
A controlled list of approved subcontractors, including scope of work, locations and date of last audit, is maintained in Appendix XX."
If subcontracting is not used, clearly state that this procedure is not applicable and remove references to a subcontractor catalogue, or mark it as "Not applicable – no subcontractors used".

findings.requirement_excerpt: Maintain any aircraft and/or component for which it is approved at a location identified as a line maintenance location … and only if the organisation exposition both permits such activity and lists such locations;
findings.reasoning: The MOE text mentions a 'CATALOG TEMPORARY LINE MAINTENANCE POINTS', which suggests an intention to list line maintenance locations, including temporary ones. However, no actual procedure is described for how such locations are established, controlled, or approved, and no explicit statement is made that the MOE lists all line maintenance locations as required. Without a clear procedure and reference to where the list is maintained, compliance is only partial.

findings.requirement_excerpt: Issue certificates of release to service in respect of completion of maintenance in accordance with point 145.A.50;
findings.reasoning: The MOE text only contains the phrase 'MAINTENANCE CERTIFICATE GIVING (HTA) CATALOG' without any explanation. It is unclear whether this refers to a procedure for issuing certificates of release to service, a list of authorised certifying staff, or something else. No actual process, responsibilities, or reference to 145.A.50 is described in the provided excerpt.
findings.recommended_fix:
Clarify and expand this part of the MOE to describe the certificate of release to service (CRS) process, for example:
"X.X Certificates of Release to Service (CRS)
(a) The organisation issues certificates of release to service in accordance with 145.A.50 upon completion of maintenance.
(b) Only certifying staff authorised in accordance with Section X.X 'Authorisation of Certifying Staff' may issue a CRS.
(c) The 'CRS/HTA Catalogue' (Appendix ZZ) lists all certifying staff, their authorisation numbers, scope of authorisation (aircraft types/components) and validity dates.
(d) The CRS is issued on [describe form or system] and includes at least: aircraft/ component identification, work performed, reference to maintenance data, date of completion, and identification/signature of the certifying staff.
(e) The organisation retains CRS records in accordance with the record-keeping procedure in Section X.X."
Ensure that the term 'HTA' is defined or replaced with standard terminology (e.g. 'certifying staff authorisation').
